title: The United States’ Unamendable Constitution
alt: The inflation calculator interface and a chart of inflation data.
info: I contributed data visualization and development to this article by historian Jill Lepore about the history of efforts to amend the U.S. Constitution. Components included a set of interactive survey questions exploring Americans' attitudes toward the Constitution, as well as a longform annotated timeline visualizing more than 10,000 failed amendments.

title: Inflation calculator: How do rising prices affect your personal finances?
alt: The inflation calculator interface and a chart of inflation data.
info: With inflation dominating the headlines, I built this calculator to allow Canadians to see in depth how rising prices affect their own budgets. The project uses GitHub Actions to automatically process and publish monthly inflation data releases from Statistics Canada. In the interactive app, built with Svelte, users can select a province and plug in numbers from their own budget to see how much their spending has increased over time.

title: Inside COVID's 'Invisible Hospitals'
alt: A map of hospital locations in Toronto.
info: I developed an immersive scrollytelling presentation for this multimedia investigation into three COVID patients' rehabilitation journeys. The piece incorporates video, audio, photography, maps, and text, all orchestrated by a custom-built Svelte app. I also created a new template within the Global News WordPress theme to allow publication of the statically rendered project files within the CMS.

title: Explore Nearly 2,000 Gun Dealer Inspection Reports
alt: A map and table of gun dealer inspections.
info: For this investigation into the federal government's failure to regulate gun dealers, co-published with USA TODAY, I also parsed and analyzed thousands of pages of documents in Node and R, and then published them in this interactive database built with Sapper and Airtable. I produced explanatory scrollytelling components for the main feature story using Svelte. Shortly after publication, Congressional Democrats introduced legislation to tighten the penalties for lawbreaking gun dealers.

title: A Historic Surge in Gun Violence Compounds the Traumas of 2020
alt: Chart comparing mass shootings in 2020 to previous years.
info: This story was an attempt to make sense of the surge of gun violence that accompanied the social upheavals of 2020. Centering the perspectives of violence prevention workers and members of communities that bear the brunt of gun violence, it also incorporates national and city-level crime data and rich photography to create a holistic picture of the toll guns took in 2020.

title: How Many Guns Did Americans Buy Last Month?
alt: Table showing state-level estimates of gun sales.
info: The FBI's monthly gun background check data became major news amid 2020's coronavirus fears and social unrest, but the top-line numbers lack important context. To give readers a clearer picture of the trend, I built this gun sales explainer and database, using the raw FBI numbers to produce seasonally adjusted sales estimates at the national and state level. My analysis draws on the work of economist Jurgen Brauer, as well as prior analyses by BuzzFeed News and The New York Times. The project updates on a monthly basis as new data is released.

title: svelte-canvas
alt: Screenshot of a scatterplot visualization built with svelte-canvas.
info: Svelte has been my go-to framework for a few years now, and I recently created this small library which provides an idiomatic wrapper component for the <canvas> element. Users can create layer components that encapsulate individual portions of the canvas, and write reactive render functions that redraw whenever the variables that they depend on change. The library enables canvas-based interactive visualizations to be built using familiar Svelte conventions.

title: Gun Shops Flouted State Closure Orders in April as Industry Notched Another Big Month
alt: Charts showing levels of gun violence in cities under lockdown.
info: In the early days of the pandemic, five states declared gun dealers nonessential under their stay-at-home orders. Federal background check data revealed that gun sales continued in all of those states. Reporting with my colleague Champe Barton, we found a pattern of stores openly defying shutdown orders, and states hesitant to take action against them. This story was co-published with USA TODAY.

title: Shootings Are a Glaring Exception to the Coronavirus Crime Drop
alt: Charts showing levels of gun violence in cities under lockdown.
info: While coronavirus lockdowns caused most types of violent crime to decrease, my analysis found that gun violence was up nationally and in several major cities. Using data from Gun Violence Archive and cities' open data portals, I tracked rates of gun murders and assaults, as well as other types of violent crime, comparing them against the baseline rates of the past several years. In every city, gun violence remained elevated compared to other violent crime, and a couple saw dramatic spikes.

title: Most Shooters Go Free in Chicago’s Most Violent Neighborhoods — While Police Make Non-Stop Drug Arrests
alt: A map of shootings in Chicago's 11th police district.
info: I produced graphics and assisted with the data analysis for my colleague Sarah Ryley's look at unequal policing in Chicago. We found that law enforcement prioritized arrests for simple drug offenses while failing to make arrests in the vast majority of shootings. Out of a massive amount of data, I built a few maps and charts to drive home the most crucial findings. This article was also published by WTTW, Chicago's PBS affiliate.

title: Fireproofing the Future in California
alt: Map of wildfire area in California.
info: I created two maps for this New Yorker/Van Alen Institute video about California's wildfire epidemic, one showing the extent of wildfire footprints around Santa Rosa and one illustrating wildfire risk zones statewide. I pulled geospatial data from CAL FIRE and the US Census Bureau, processed it in R using the sf library, built the maps in D3 using shaded relief layers from SRTM, and delivered them as SVGs to an animator who produced the final visuals that appeared in the video.

title: Since Parkland
alt: Since Parkland project homepage.
info: This project, which tells the stories of more than a thousand children killed by gun violence, was a huge collaboration between The Trace, The Miami Herald/McClatchy, and more than 200 student journalists, with a standalone website built by Upstatement. I worked closely with the Upstatement team and fellow Trace staff to conceive the design and functionality of the project site — my contributions included key features such as the category-driven navigation and star motifs. I also coordinated a team-wide push to prepare the site's content for production in Google Docs and AirTable.

title: America’s Gun Stores Are Easy Targets for Thieves
alt: Map of arrows representing the volume of guns traced between states.
info: I worked with reporter Brian Freskos and The New Yorker's digital team to create two Mapbox maps for this multimedia feature built in React. The first illustrates ATF crime gun traces by connecting states with swoopy arrows, which were drawn with Turf.js and baked out to GeoJSON files. The second uses a scroll-driven flyover to explore the locations where several dozen stolen guns were recovered.

title: An Atlas of American Gun Violence
alt: Map of shooting incidents in Brooklyn.
info: Using a dataset provided by Gun Violence Archive, I built this interactive map of more than 150,000 shooting incidents spanning five years. To tackle the challenge of smoothly mapping that many points, I used the incredibly performant deck.gl library along with Mapbox, React, and Redux. A search feature shows users the number of shootings in their vicinity by linking the Mapbox geocoding API with Turf.js's geospatial analysis tools. I did a Q&A about this project that was published on Mapbox's Points of Interest blog.

title: NRA Campaign Spending Tracker
alt: Table of NRA campaign finance data.
info: I built this news app to track the NRA's spending activity during the 2018 midterms, using data from the FEC and ProPublica's Campaign Finance API. An accompanying Twitter bot tweeted every time new activity ed in the tracker, and also posted calls for key NRA races on election night. The project's serverless backend ran on AWS Lambda and the frontend was built in Svelte.

title: The CDC Says Gun Injuries Are on the Rise. But There Are Big Problems With Its Data.
alt: Chart comparing CDC firearm injury trends with two other pubic health databases.
info: Sean Campbell and I teamed up with FiveThirtyEight's quantitative editor Mai Nguyen to investigate the flawed approach used by the CDC to generate estimates of nonfatal firearm injuries. We developed a methodology for comparing the trends indicated by the CDC's data with those in other public health datasets, and found that the high degree of uncertainty around the CDC's estimates had serious implications for public health research in the United States. This article and its follow-up prompted a group of senators to demand answers from the Secretary of Health and Human Services about the CDC's data quality issues.

title: The Mystery Firm That Has Become the NRA’s Top Election Consultant
alt: Chart visualizing the NRA's spending with a campaign finance contractor.
info: For Mike Spies' story on the NRAs's dealings with its top election contractor, I created charts and an interactive explainer to illustrate the convoluted scheme. The reporting and subsequent follow-ups led to a congressional investigation into the NRA's relationship with the firms. The article and accompanying graphics were also published in Politico.

title: The Unchecked Influence of NRA Lobbyist Marion Hammer
alt: Map visualizing the NRA grades of Florida lawmakers.
info: For a feature on NRA lobbyist Marion Hammer, I collaborated with The New Yorker's digital team to create an interactive map illustrating the NRA grades of every Florida lawmaker. I sourced the data from the NRA's archive, and built the map with D3. The graphic was published on The Trace and in The New Yorker's version of the article.

title: The Florida Loophole That Lets Thousands of People Banned From Guns Get Away With Lying on Background Checks
alt: Photo illustration of a gun and a background check form.
info: I partnered with Scripps reporter Katie LaGrone to investigate a little-known loophole in Florida's firearm backround check system that prevents the state from prosecuting buyers for lying about their criminal histories. In addition to the article, a televised segment based on our reporting aired on three Scripps-owned stations in south Florida.

title: Rising Firearm Theft Is Quietly Fueling Violent Crime
alt: Interactive data visualization about gun theft in major U.S. cities.
info: The Trace's Brian Freskos launched an enormous investigation into gun theft by requesting data on stolen and recovered guns from hundreds of law enforcement agencies around the country. I helped to clean and analyze that data, writing scripts to normalize hundreds of spelling variations, identify errors in serial numbers, and comb through the records to match stolen and recovered firearms. We partnered with more than a dozen NBC stations, who used the data, as well as graphics I produced, to report on gun theft in cities around the country. We also published the raw data. This project was awarded Best Reporting by Independent Digital Media at the 2018 Deadline Club Awards.

title: Quiz: How Much Do You Know About Gun Violence in America?
alt: Interactive quiz about gun violence in America.
info: I designed and coded this news quiz on gun violence in America, which also ran in the Huffington Post. A simple Firebase backend saves user responses in a database.

title: Visualising Cambodia's national budget
alt: Treemap diagram of four years of Cambodia's national budget data.
info: In Cambodia, public data is scarce and often difficult to access. When I got ahold of four years of national budget figures, I built this interactive budget explorer to make the data available as a public resource.

title: History of crimes, ineptitude for Cambodia's flag of convenience scheme
alt: A map of a Cambodian ship's movements between China and North Korea.
info: Until 2016, Cambodia ran a flag of convenience program, under which foreign nationals could register their ships to fly the Cambodian flag. To investigate the program's shady history, I scraped GPS tracking data for hundreds of Cambodian-flagged vessels, which reporter Jack Davies and I combed through to identify ships that had called at ports in North Korea and Crimea. I also designed the article's maps.

title: The changing face of Phnom Penh
alt: Satellite map presentation showcasing timelapses of major infrastructure developments in Phnom Penh.
info: The city of Phnom Penh is being dramatically — and often violently — transformed by large-scale construction and land reclamation projects. For this interactive, I created immersive time lapses of Google Earth satellite imagery to illustrate the city's astonishing pace of growth. A locator map built in Mapbox provides geographic context.

title: Inside the Hun family's business empire
alt: Visualization of the business holdings of Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen's extended family.
info: A Global Witness report detailing the vast business holdings of Hun Sen's extended family served as the basis for this interactive, my first ever D3 project. This article was also published in Khmer.
